questions.scenario: An elderly lady is found confused by her daughter. She has a cough and her chest X-ray shows consolidation on the right lower lobe.
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is
pneumonia. The features suggesting pneumonia include:
Cough
Consolidation on chest X-ray
Delirium means acute confusion. The commonest cause of delirium in the elderly is infection such as pneumonia or UTI

Wernicke's encephalopathy is a triad of confusion, ataxia and ophthalmoplegia.

questions.subtitle: Investigations after starting treatment
questions.instructions: Each of the options may be used once, more than once or not at all.
questions.scenario: 60-year-old man with a cholesterol level of 6.6 mmol/L (Normal < 5mmol/L) has been started on atorvastatin.
options: C. Liver function tests and urea and electrolytes
questions.explanation:
Side-effects of statin include:
GI upset such as constipation, diarrhoea, flatulence.
Rhabdomyolysis  (features include myalgia and tea-coloured urine,
elevated
creatinine kinase)
Hepatic disorders (raised LFTs)
Before starting statins, a liver function test is done
After starting statins, a liver function test is checked every 3months and at 12 months.

questions.subtitle: Investigations after starting treatment
questions.instructions: Each of the options may be used once, more than once or not at all.
questions.scenario: 45-year-old man is diagnosed with hypertension and has been prescribed Lisinopril.
options: C. Liver function tests and urea and electrolytes
questions.explanation:
ACE inhibitors are nephrotoxic.
Therefore Urea and Electrolytes are checked at the start of treatment, repeated 1-2 weeks after starting treatment and after each increase in ACEI dose.

questions.subtitle: Investigations after starting treatment
questions.instructions: Each of the options may be used once, more than once or not at all.
questions.scenario: 45-year-old man with supraventricular tachycardia has been started on amiodarone.
options: C. Liver function tests and urea and electrolytes
questions.explanation: Amiodarone can cause disruption of the normal functioning of several organs like the thyroid, liver, kidneys, lungs and heart. Therefore it is essential to regularly monitor thyroid function tests, liver function tests, urea & electrolytes and ECG for patients on amiodarone. From the options above both Liver function tests and urea & electrolyte are most important to be regularly checked.

Age (the risk of stroke doubles every decade after the age of 55 years)
Slurred speech and weakness
the left lower part of his face

eurological symptoms

Hypertension (risk factor for stroke)
Antiplatelet medications should not be administered until hemorrhagic stroke has been excluded by investigations such as CT scan of the brain.
While awaiting transfer:

Give supplemental oxygen to people with acute stroke if oxygen saturation is less than 95% and there are no contraindications.

questions.scenario: 25-year-old woman presents with pain in the wrists which is more marked in the metacarpal phalangeal joints of both hands.
options: E. Anti cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is rheumatoid arthritis.
Features suggesting RA include:
Gender of the patient (RA is common in females than males),
Bilateral, symmetrical involvement of the wrists and the metacarpal-phalangeal joints.
Small joint involvement (affecting hands and wrists)
The most specific test of rheumatoid arthritis is Anti cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies.

questions.subtitle: No subtitle
questions.instructions: What is the SINGLE most appropriate NEXT step in management?
questions.scenario: 50-year-old man was found lying unconscious on the street by the ambulance crew at the scene. His capillary blood glucose at the scene is 1.9 mol/l.
questions.explanation:
The patient has hypoglycemia because his blood glucose is 1.9 mmol/L (normal glucose is 3.5-5.5
mmol/ litre)
. Intramuscular glucagon is the first line of treatment for acute hypoglycaemia in an unconscious patient when IV access can't be rapidly established.
Hypoglycaemia
Hypoglycaemia is defined as blood glucose <3.0 mmol/ litre
There are 3 main criteria for diagnosis of hypoglycaemia (Whipple's triad)
Plasma hypoglycaemia
Symptoms of hypoglycaemia
Resolution of symptoms with the treatment of the hypoglycaemia
Causes
Alcohol
People with diabetes treated with insulin or sulphonylureas
Other drugs such as paracetamol
Rare causes (if insulin and C-peptide levels are elevated, an endogenous insulin source is the cause)
Pancreatic and endocrine tumours e.g. insulinoma
Autoimmune hypoglycaemia
Starvation e.g. anorexia nervosa
Insulinomas
Insulinomas
usually cause a semi-autonomous release of insulin resulting in fasting hypoglycaemia
A typical presentation is whenever the patient misses meals he suffers a hypoglycaemic attack
Symptoms of hypoglycaemia
Shaking and trembling
Sweating, pins and needles in the lips and tongue
Hunger, palpitations
Headache
Double vision
Difficult to concentrate
Agitation, aggression
Seizure
Coma
Feeling hungry
Investigations
Plasma glucose concentration
C-peptide may be measured to differentiate between endogenous and exogenous insulin
If C-peptide is raised then it is endogenous hyperinsulinaemia
Exogenous insulin-induced hypoglycaemia can be detected by insulin to C-peptide ratio greater than 1 (i.e. insulin: C-peptide greater than 1)
Management:
If the patient is unconscious
75–80 ml of 20% glucose or 150–160 ml of 10% glucose
50 ml of 50% glucose concentration is irritant to veins and difficult to administer. It is rarely used now
If the patient is conscious
Glucose 10–20 g given by mouth, either in a liquid form or as granulated sugar (2 teaspoons) or sugar lumps
GlucoGel is formerly known as Hypostop gel
Check capillary blood glucose after
10–15 minutes
; if the patient is still hypoglycaemic then the above treatment can be repeated up to 3 times.
If the patient is at home, or if intravenous (IV) access cannot be rapidly established:
Glucagon 1 mg IM or SC
Once the patient regains consciousness, oral glucose should be administered

questions.subtitle: Monitoring of Medication
questions.instructions: Each of the options may be used once, more than once or not at all.
questions.scenario: 56-year-old man with diabetes has been treated for a fungal nail infection with terbinafine.
questions.explanation:
One of the side-effects of anti-fungal (Terbutaline) is liver toxicity.
It is recommended to monitor liver function tests periodically after 4 – 6 weeks of treatment
If the patient develops an abnormal liver function test then anti-fungal medication needs to be discontinued.

questions.explanation:
One of the side effects of statins is muscle effects such as myopathy, myositis and rhabdomyolitis.
If the creatine kinase concentration is markedly raised or the patient has severe symptoms, statin needs to be discontinued.
